direct_answer.text: First, let us calculate the length of one complete tour around the square formed by connecting our chosen points ($ABCD$). According to Pythagorean Theorem applied twice, since every side forms right angles triangle together with adjacent sides : $$AC=BC\sqrt{2} \text {   }$$and also ,$$AD=DB\sqrt{2}\text{ .}$$Since both triangles share base BC, it holds true that $$\frac{DC}{AD}=1.$$This further leads to DC=$AD$, therefore DB equals CD.$|AD|$+$|BC|$ being equal to $|DC|$ plus $|BA|$ implies |AB|=$4*|\text{$AD$}|$ hence making full circumference($P$)equal to $|AB|$plus $|\text{DBC}|$which simplifies into absolute valueofsummedlengthsinvolvedinourtourspaths:$p=a+b+c+d+\color{red}{\underbrace{|DB|}}_{\text{one segment}},\quad p_{min}=\max\{p,\,f\}$. Here,$F=[(\bar{DA}+\bar{BB})\cdot (\bar{CA}-\bar{CC})]\left|\begin{array}{|l|r l||l r|

First let us observe how close each corner node ($A,$ $B,$ $C,$ and $D$) is connected to every single other one via edges. If our starting point were located anywhere but vertex $D$, it would require passing through either edge $AC$ twice along some route since both corners lie directly adjacent to vertex $D.$ However, as stated earlier, no matter what path taken passes outside of vertex $D$ before returning back again—this violates the problem condition stating vertices may only traverse paths connecting *adjacent* nodes (*directly next door*) until reaching destination -- thus eliminating options like those shown below... direct_answer.text: Starting anywhere doesn't change the outcome significantly when optimizing routes like this one. However, different starting points could mean slightly varied intermediate steps depending on what configuration results in fewer moves. Yet, it remains evident that no matter the chosen coordinate, completing this circuit requires covering each border exactly once. Hence, the minimum required movement equals double the perimeter minus four sides—resulting in |AB|+|BC|+|CD|+|DA|=(√[(1-2)+(−1+2)]²+(−2+2)²)+((−2-1)²+(1+1)²)+((1+0)²+(-1-0)²)+((2-1)²+(−1-2)²). Calculating everything out gets us ((1)(-1) + (-2)(1) ) + ((-2)(1) + (2)(1)) + ((1)(1) + (-1)(1)) + ((2)(1) + (-1)(-2)), simplifying into equal movements totalling five unit lengths.
